hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Hanash al-San'ani: We made an expedition with Ruwayfi' ibn Thabit, may Allah be pleased with him, and we conquered a village called Jarabbah. Ruwayfi' ibn Thabit stood among us as a speaker and said: I do not stand before you except with what I heard from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ stood on the day of Khaibar after conquering it and said: Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not touch any of the captives until he verifies their status. Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not ride any animal from the Muslims' spoils until he has worn it out, then he returns it to them. Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not wear any garment from the Muslims' spoils until he has worn it out, then he returns it to them.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Yahya ibn Asad ibn Zurayra: I heard my uncle Yahya and I have not found anyone among us similar to him in how he narrates to people. Asad ibn Zurayra, the maternal grandfather of Muhammad, was afflicted with a pain in his throat called al-Dhubh. The Prophet ﷺ said: It is not sufficient or will not excuse Abu Umamah. He cauterized him with his hand and he died. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: How bad is the condition for the Jews who say: Why did he not defend his companion? I have no power for him nor for myself in anything.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Imran ibn Hayyan al-Ansari: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ addressed the people on the day of Khaibar. He made lawful for them three things that he had forbidden them, and forbade them three things that the people considered lawful. He made lawful for them: the flesh of sacrificial animals, visiting graves, and vessels. He forbade them that a share of spoils should be sold until it is divided, he forbade them regarding women (that they should be approached) until they give birth, and he forbade that fruit should be sold until its ripeness becomes apparent.
